Research Article
Special Issue: In honor of Robert Fefferman
Marjorie Drake, Charles Fefferman, Kevin Ren and Anna Skorobogatova*
Sobolev extension in a simple case
https://doi.org/10.1515/ans-2023-0132
Received February 18, 2024; accepted March 24, 2024; published online May 24, 2024
Abstract: In this paper, we establish the existence of a bounded, linear extension operator T : L 2, p (E) â†’ L 2, p (â„ 2 )
when 1 < p < 2 and E is a finite subset of â„ 2 contained in a line.
Keywords: Sobolev extension; linear extension; Whitney extension; CalderÃ³n-Zygmund decomposition
MSC code: 46E35
text.body:
1 Introduction
Continuing from [1]-[6], we study the Sobolev extension problem: given a finite set E âŠ‚ â„ n and a function
f : E â†’ â„, our task is to find a function F in the homogeneous Sobolev space L m, p (â„ n ) satisfying F = f on E such
that â€–Fâ€– L m, p (â„ n ) has the least possible order of magnitude. Moreover, we want to compute the order of magnitude
of â€–Fâ€– L m, p (â„ n ) . Here, L m, p (â„ n ) denotes the homogeneous Sobolev spaces consisting of functions F on â„ n whose
distributional derivatives of order m belong to L p , with seminorm
â€–Fâ€– L m, p (â„ n ) :=

Notice that when p > n
m , any function F âˆˆ L m, p (â„ n ) is continuous, so the restriction F| E to any finite subset
E âŠ‚ â„ n is well-defined. Thus, our requirement that F = f on E makes sense for any choice of f and our problem
is well-posed provided that p > n
m .
In the narrower parameter range p > n, the problem is well-understood; see Israel [3], Fefferman-Israel-
Luli [1], [2] and Drake [7]. We recall the relevant results as follows. Let L m, p (E) denote the space of functions
f : E â†’ â„ equipped with the seminorm
â€– f â€– L m, p (E) := inf{â€–Fâ€– L m, p (â„ n ) : F âˆˆ L m, p (â„ n ), F = f on E}.
For p > n and E âŠ‚ â„ n finite, there exist a linear map T: L m, p (E) â†’ L m, p (â„ n ), and linear functionals
ğ“ 1 , â€¦ , ğ“ ğœˆ max : L m, p (E) â†’ â„, with the following properties:

Here, the constants C m,n, p and c m,n, p depend only on m, n, p, the parameters specifying the Sobolev
space.
(3) Moreover, the number ğœˆ max of linear functionals ğ“ ğœˆ grows only linearly with N, the number of points of E,
and the ğ“ ğœˆ have a sparse structure that lets us evaluate ||| f ||| p in O(N) computer operations. The functionals
ğ“ ğœˆ and the operator T can be computed efficiently. See [1] for details.
When n
m < p â‰¤ n, the proofs of the above results break down, and we know almost nothing. In this paper,
we analyze the simplest non-trivial case. We work in the homogeneous Sobolev space L 2, p (â„ 2 ) for 1 < p < 2. We
suppose our finite set E is contained in a line. Let (x, y) denote the canonical orthogonal coordinates in â„ 2 ; by
rotating our coordinates, we may assume that E lies on the x-axis. Our main results are as follows.
Fix p (1 < p < 2). Let E âŠ‚ â„ Ã— {0} âŠ‚ â„ 2 be finite, with N = #E â‰¥ 2. We write c, C, C â€² , etc. to denote absolute
constants, and we write c p , C p , C â€²
p , etc. to denote constants depending only on p.
Theorem 1. There exists a linear map T: L 2, p (E) â†’ L 2, p (â„ 2 ) such that Tf = f on E and â€–T f â€– L 2, p (â„ 2 ) â‰¤ C p â€– f â€– L 2, p (E)
for every f âˆˆ L 2, p (E). Moreover, we can take T independent of p, such that for each point z âˆˆ â„ 2 , the value of Tf
at z is determined by the value of f at at most C points of E.
Further, under the same assumptions as in Theorem 1, we can efficiently compute the order of magnitude
of â€– f â€– L 2, p (E) :
Theorem 2. There exist positive constants ğœ† 1 , â€¦ , ğœ† ğœˆ max âˆˆ â„ and linear functionals ğ“ 1 , â€¦ , ğ“ ğœˆ max : L 2, p (E) â†’ â„ such
that the quantity ||| f ||| p :=
(âˆ‘ ğœˆ max
ğœˆ=1 ğœ† ğœˆ |ğ“ ğœˆ ( f )| p ) 1âˆ• p satisfies
c p ||| f ||| p â‰¤ â€– f â€– L 2, p (E) â‰¤ C p ||| f ||| p
for all f âˆˆ L 2, p (E).
Moreover, we can take ğœ† ğœˆ , ğ“ ğœˆ independent of p such that ğœˆ max â‰¤ CN for N = #E, and for each ğœˆ, the quantity
ğ“ ğœˆ ( f ) is determined by the value of f at at most C points of E.
The remainder of the paper is dedicated to the proof of Theorem 1 and Theorem 2.
Remark 1.1. The conclusions of Theorem 1 and Theorem 2 remain open for an arbitrary choice of finite subset
E âŠ‚ â„ 2 . See Carruth-Israel [8] for a class of examples in which E is contained in a union of two closely-spaced
parallel lines and substantial new issues arise. See also Feerman-Klartag [9].
Before proceeding, let us first outline an important issue arising in the proof of Theorem 1 and Theorem 2
and the corresponding key new ingredient introduced here to deal with this. Note that this discussion is merely
an overview; see the relevant succeeding sections for a more precise description. Fix 1 < p < 2 and suppose we
are given f : E â†’ â„. We will make a CalderÃ³n-Zygmund (henceforth abbreviated by CZ) decomposition in the
plane. Figure 1 depicts two possible scenarios for a CZ square Q, whose distance to the x-axis is comparable to
its side length ğ›¿ Q , together with nearby points in E. In Figure 1a, |z 1 -z 2 | is comparable to ğ›¿ Q , while in Figure 1b,
|z 1 -z 2 | is much smaller than ğ›¿ Q , while |z * -z 1 | is much larger than ğ›¿ Q .

Figure 1: Two possible scenarios for a CZ square Q. (a) z 1 , z 2 âˆˆ E near Q with |z 1 -z 2 | â‰ƒ ğ›¿ Q . (b) z 1 , z 2 , z * âˆˆ E near Q with |z 1 -z 2 | â‰ª ğ›¿ Q
and |z * -z 1 | â‰« ğ›¿ Q .
More precisely, the points z 1 , z 2 , z * belong to E and all other points of E lie much farther away from Q than
those depicted. Let F âˆˆ L 2, p (â„ 2 ) satisfy F = f on E with â€–Fâ€– L 2, p (â„ 2 ) being of least possible order of magnitude.
What can we infer about the behavior of F on Q? In particular, what can we say about ğœ• x F on Q?
If z 1 , z 2 and Q are as in Figure 1a, one expects that ğœ• x F| Q is closely approximated by the difference quotient

On the other hand, suppose that z 1 , z 2 , z * and Q are as in Figure 1b. This time, since |z 1 -z 2 | â‰ª ğ›¿ Q , DQ(z 1 , z 2 )
is not an effective approximation for ğœ• x F| Q . Instead, the difference quotient DQ

to avoid having unbounded overlaps when summing over all squares Q, we cannot simply consider a single
such square Q associated to Q * .
Instead, for a fixed z * âˆˆ E, we group together all CZ squares Q for which a scenario like that in Figure 1b
holds for z * . We denote this subcollection of the CZ squares by GP(z * ). Thanks to a lemma in Section 8, the
structure of the squares in GP(z * ) looks like that depicted in Figure 2.

Q in isolation, then sum over all Q together.
So our main new ingredient is the introduction of GP(z * ). By making a translation and dilation of E, we may
assume without loss of generality that E = E Ã— {0} âŠ‚ â„ 2 for a finite subset E with max E = 2 -11 and min E =

Theorem 3. Let E âŠ‚ â„ Ã— {0} âŠ‚ â„ 2 be finite with N = #E â‰¥ 2. Let X(E) denote the vector space of real-valued
functions on E. Then there exists a linear map T â™¯ : X(E) â†’

The constants C in (d), (e), and (f), are universal, so independent of the set E and the function f .

3 Constants
Let 1 < p < 2. Fix p = 1+ p
2 âˆˆ (1, p). We write c, C, C â€² to denote absolute constants and we write c p , C p , C â€²
p to
denote constants depending only on p. We may use the same symbol to denote different constants in different
occurrences.
Let K > 0 be larger than some absolute constant. We write
c(K), C(K), C â€² (K),
to denote constants depending only on K. Once again, the same symbol could be used to denote different
occurrences.
At the end of Section 8, we choose K to be an absolute constant, taken sufficiently large. Once we do so, K
and any instances of C(K) become absolute constants C.
4 Dyadic squares and intervals
Here, dyadic squares are Q 0 = [-1, 1] 2 âŠ‚ â„ 2 and all closed squares arising from Q 0 by successive bisection. More
precisely, any dyadic square Q is either Q 0 or of the form [i2 -k , (i + 1)2 -k ] Ã— [j2 -k , (j + 1)2 -k ], for some k âˆˆ â„• âˆª
{0} and i, j âˆˆ {-2 k , . . . , 2 k -1}. Similarly, dyadic intervals consist of the interval I 0 = [-1, 1] âŠ‚ â„ and all the
closed intervals [i2 -k , (i + 1)2 -k ] for i âˆˆ {-2 k , . . . , 2 k -1} and k âˆˆ â„•, obtained by successive bisection of I 0 . Note
that dyadic squares and intervals are closed.
If Q is any dyadic square, we denote its side length by ğ›¿ Q and if I is a dyadic interval, we denote its length by
|I|. Moreover, we denote the area ğ›¿ 2
Q of a dyadic square Q by |Q|. Each dyadic square Q of side length ğ›¿ Q â‰¤ 1 arises
by bisecting a dyadic square Q + âŠƒ Q of side length 2ğ›¿ Q ; we call Q + the dyadic parent of Q. Similarly, each dyadic
interval I of length |I| â‰¤ 1 arises by bisecting a dyadic interval I + âŠƒ I of length 2|I|; we call I + the dyadic parent
of I.
If I is a dyadic interval and C > 1, then CI denotes the open interval of length C|I| whose center coincides
with that of I. Similarly, if Q is a dyadic square and C > 1âˆ•4 (C â‰ 1), then CQ denotes the open square of side
length Cğ›¿ Q whose center coincides with that of Q.
Throughout this article, we will make frequent use of the square Q inner := [-2 -10 , 2 -10 ] 2 âŠ‚ Q 0 .

in the form F 1 + L on Q, where L is a first degree polynomial and F 1 is continuous on Q; moreover,

7 The CalderÃ³n-Zygmund decomposition
Starting with the square Q 0 , we perform repeated bisection Ã la CalderÃ³n-Zygmund, stopping at a square Q

CalderÃ³n-Zygmund squares. Equivalently, the CZ squares are precisely the maximal dyadic squares Q such that

9 Assigning special points to CZ squares
Let Q be a RELEVANT CZ square. We will associate to Q three points of E + , denoted z 1 (Q), z 2 (Q), z(Q), as follows.
Recall from Lemma 8.1 that a RELEVANT CZ square is either EASY, or else it belongs to GP(z * ) for a unique
z * âˆˆ E + . Using this dichotomy, we proceed to define z 1 (Q), z 2 (Q) âˆˆ E + for any RELEVANT CZ square Q.
(a) If Q is EASY, then by the defining property (8.1), there exist two points z 1 , z 2 âˆˆ E + âˆ© CQ such that |z 1 -z 2 | â‰¥
cğ›¿ Q . Define z 1 (Q) := z 1 and z 2 (Q) := z 2 .
(b) If Q is HARD and belongs to GP(z * ) for some z * âˆˆ E + , then recall from Lemma 8.5 that the CZ square Q big (z * )
is EASY. Hence, z 1 (Q big (z * )) and z 2 (Q big (z * )) have already been defined in case (a). Define z 1 (Q) := z 1 (Q big (z * ))
and z 2 (Q) := z 2 (Q big (z * )). Note that since Q big (z * ) is EASY, |z 1 (Q) -z 2 (Q)| â‰¥ cğ›¿ Q big (z * ) .
Now, we define the points z(Q) âˆˆ E. We proceed by cases. Let Q be a RELEVANT CZ square.

11 Removing the extra point from E +
Observe that Lemma 10.2 concludes Theorem 3, up to getting rid of the extra point (-1, 0) âˆˆ E + âˆ– E. To do so, we
introduce a trivial extension operator as follows.
Recall that E âŠ‚ [-2 -11 , 2 -11 ] Ã— {0} âŠ‚ â„ 2 and that (2 -11 , 0), (-2 -11 , 0) âˆˆ E. Given a function F âˆˆ L 2, p (Q inner ),
we let L F be the unique first degree polynomial that agrees with F at the points (-2 -11 , 0), (2 -11 , 0) and (2 -11 , 2 -11 ).
Then, using Corollaries 5.1-5.3, the Hardy-Littlewood Maximal Theorem, and that ğ›¿ Q inner = 2 -9 , we have

This verifies conclusions (a), (b) and (c). The validity of property (d) follows from the fact that given any
point z âˆˆ â„ 2 , T â™¯ f (z) depends only on Tf evaluated at the points (Â±2 -11 , 0), (2 -11 , 2 -11 ) and z (where the latter
dependency is only if z âˆˆ Q inner ). Thanks to conclusion (v) of Lemma 11.1, (d) indeed follows.
In light of (vi) and (vii) of Lemma 11.1, conclusions (e) and (f) follow. This completes the proof.
